hints_html:
Recall (or review) the definition of the 2nd order Taylor polynomial of a function \(f(x)\) at a point \(x = a\) from your text. In this case, what is the function \(f(x)\) and what is \(a\)?

Recall that the second order Taylor polynomial of a function \(f(x)\) at a point \(x = a\) is given by \(T_{2}(x)\) where,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle T_{2}(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a) + \frac{1}{2}f''(a)(x-a)^{2}\end{aligned}\]

In our case, \(a=1\) and \(f(x) = \arctan(x)\).

Recall the derivative of arctan(x)

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx} \arctan(x) = \frac1{1+x^2}\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex:
Recall (or review) the definition of the 2nd order Taylor polynomial of
a function $f(x)$ at a point $x = a$ from your text. In this case, what
is the function $f(x)$ and what is $a$?
hints_raw:
Recall (or review) the definition of the 2nd order Taylor polynomial of a function <math>f(x)</math> at a point <math>x = a</math> from your text. In this case, what is the function <math>f(x)</math> and what is <math>a</math>?
Recall that the second order Taylor polynomial of a function <math>f(x)</math> at a point <math>x = a</math> is given by <math>T_{2}(x)</math> where,
:<math>
\displaystyle T_{2}(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a) + \frac{1}{2}f''(a)(x-a)^{2}
</math>

In our case, <math> a=1 </math> and <math> f(x) = \arctan(x) </math>.
Recall the derivative of ''arctan(x)''

:<math>
\frac{d}{dx} \arctan(x) = \frac1{1+x^2}
</math>
question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
For our problem, we have that \(a = 1\) and \(f(x) = \arctan(x)\). Evaluating the derivatives, we get

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = \frac{1}{1 + x^{2}}, \quad f''(x) = \frac{-2x}{(1 + x^{2})^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

Thus,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(1) = \arctan(1) = \frac{\pi}{4}, \quad f'(1) = \frac{1}{2}, \quad f''(1) = -\frac{1}{2}\end{aligned}\]

and so the 2nd order Taylor polynomial is

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}T_{2}(x) = \frac{\pi}{4} + \frac{1}{2}(x - 1) - \frac{1}{4}(x -1)^{2}}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
For our problem, we have that <math>a = 1</math> and <math>f(x) = \arctan(x)</math>. Evaluating the derivatives, we get
:<math>
f'(x) = \frac{1}{1 + x^{2}}, \quad f''(x) = \frac{-2x}{(1 + x^{2})^{2}}
</math>
Thus,
:<math>
\displaystyle
f(1) = \arctan(1) = \frac{\pi}{4}, \quad f'(1) = \frac{1}{2}, \quad f''(1) = -\frac{1}{2}
</math>
and so the 2nd order Taylor polynomial is
:<math>
{\color{blue}T_{2}(x) = \frac{\pi}{4} + \frac{1}{2}(x - 1) - \frac{1}{4}(x - 1)^{2}}.
</math>
statement_html:
Find the second order Taylor polynomial for

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}y=\arctan(x)\end{aligned}\]

at x=1.
statement_raw:
Find the second order Taylor polynomial for

:<math>
\displaystyle{}y=\arctan(x)
</math>

at x=1.
